awd_titl_txt: Large Scale Structure Studies on a Value Added Galaxy Catalog
awd_abstract_narration:
New statistical and machine learning techniques will create a better catalog of galaxies.  This catalog will combine information from several existing surveys.  A technique called "photometric redshifts" will give speed and distance information from study of the galaxy colors.  The result will be the widest area and deepest catalog yet available.  It will be ideal for comparing to other large area surveys, especially of the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB).  Those studies will shed light on cosmology and dark energy.  They may even show whether a more exotic theory of gravity is needed.  Education is included through special topic courses.  There are connections to national laboratories.  The methods will be introduced to students from other disciplines.

This project will create a combined value-added galaxy catalog to be called PS1*, for statistical studies of large-scale structure (LSS).  Building on experience developing a star-galaxy separation algorithm for the first PanSTARRS catalog (PS1) using Support Vector Machines (SVM) and training sets from Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) data, the work will proceed by matching Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) data, PS1, and where available, SDSS and Two Micron All Sky Survey (2MASS) objects.  The SVM algorithm will extend over the output catalog.  The resulting galaxy maps will be several times larger than SDSS, with less stellar contamination than PS1 alone, and will be deeper than WISE or 2MASS.  Previously demonstrated machine learning tools will then be used to estimate photometric redshifts for the combined sample.  The new PS1* will be the widest area, deepest photometric redshift catalog, and will be optimal for cross correlation studies with other wide data sets, such as the CMB, X-ray surveys, the cosmic infrared background, and maps of gravitational lensing.

Specific questions that will be studied include whether CMB anomalies are caused by LSS, whether superstructures that will be found in PS1* have any effect on the CMB, how the map of the Integrated Sachs-Wolfe (ISW) effect to be created from PS1* relates to the CMB map from the Planck satellite, and how well LSS statistics and cosmological parameters can be extracted.  The project will explore novel machine learning techniques for both star-galaxy separation and photometric redshifts and apply state of the art statistical techniques, shedding light on cosmological parameters and dark energy.  It will investigate any connection between LSS and CMB anomalies, and whether this is consistent with ISW or requires a more exotic theory.  The catalog will be publicly available for a variety of cross-correlation studies, and the algorithms and open source software developed will be disseminated widely.  This study promotes the integration of research into teaching through courses, internships, and including cross-disciplinary students.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Our primary objective was to create a new catalog from the PanSTARRS1 (PS1) multicolor optical survey data set. We developed Deep Neural Network (DNN) based Machine Learning (ML) methods to classify catalog objects as stars, quasars, and galaxies. We fed the colors of these galaxies into another DNN we constructed to approximate the spectroscopic redshifts due to the universe's expansion. Since objects further away recede faster, their redshift is redder. Thus photometric redshifts correspond to an approximate distance. Our publicly available galaxy catalog is the most expansive area photometric redshift catalog.

Seasonality plagues ground-based observations but has no effect on space telescopes. Therefore we took the infrared WISE catalog, which is similar in size, and matched it with the PS1 objects. We ran the same DNN-based classification and photometric redshift algorithms. The resulting WISE-PS1 catalog is as homogenous as the original space-based WISE. Still, each galaxy has optical and infrared colors, thus accurate photometric redshifts. We made this new catalog publicly available as well.

These catalogs are ideal for studying the Integrated Sachs-Wolf (ISW) effect on the largest angular scales. Photons from the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) cross potential wells when they cross superclusters. Since Dark Energy (DE) causes these potential wells to decay,  photons will gain energy as they emerge on the other side. A supercluster thus corresponds to a hot spot in the CMB. Analogously, supervoids correspond to cold spots. The effect is on enormous scales and depends on the distance of superstructures. Thus the unprecedented angular size and the distance estimates for each galaxy were crucial for studying the effect with cross-correlations of the CMB with WISE-PS1.

The ISW effect is widely considered a smoking gun of DE. Thus our measurement is a direct observation of DE, and it is the most statistically significant from a single homogenous data set. In addition, the level of the ISW effect is higher than predicted by the standard concordance model. This rare discordance adds to similar problems with the cosmological expansion rate and cosmic growth of structure. Together, they could signal that we need to refine our cosmological theories.

Our catalogs provide a three-dimensional map of the universe for about half the sky out to over 10 billion light years. The ISW effect is the first low-hanging fruit from this beautiful data set. We expect many interesting scientific analyses, some even beyond our imagination, to follow from our work on this project.


Last Modified: 12/12/2022
Modified by: Istvan Szapudi

Image
  • We selected objects selected as galaxies in our new galaxy catalog between photometric redshifts of 0.2 and 0.3. The overdensity map in Healpix projection shows the typical cosmic web. The complex geometry is a result of matching two catalogs with their distinct observational patterns.
    McPartland and Szapudi (2022)
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Istvan Szapudi
    Galaxy overdensity map from WISE-PS1
por.por_txt_cntn:
Our primary objective was to create a new catalog from the PanSTARRS1 (PS1) multicolor optical survey data set. We developed Deep Neural Network (DNN) based Machine Learning (ML) methods to classify catalog objects as stars, quasars, and galaxies. We fed the colors of these galaxies into another DNN we constructed to approximate the spectroscopic redshifts due to the universe's expansion. Since objects further away recede faster, their redshift is redder. Thus photometric redshifts correspond to an approximate distance. Our publicly available galaxy catalog is the most expansive area photometric redshift catalog.

Seasonality plagues ground-based observations but has no effect on space telescopes. Therefore we took the infrared WISE catalog, which is similar in size, and matched it with the PS1 objects. We ran the same DNN-based classification and photometric redshift algorithms. The resulting WISE-PS1 catalog is as homogenous as the original space-based WISE. Still, each galaxy has optical and infrared colors, thus accurate photometric redshifts. We made this new catalog publicly available as well.

These catalogs are ideal for studying the Integrated Sachs-Wolf (ISW) effect on the largest angular scales. Photons from the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) cross potential wells when they cross superclusters. Since Dark Energy (DE) causes these potential wells to decay,  photons will gain energy as they emerge on the other side. A supercluster thus corresponds to a hot spot in the CMB. Analogously, supervoids correspond to cold spots. The effect is on enormous scales and depends on the distance of superstructures. Thus the unprecedented angular size and the distance estimates for each galaxy were crucial for studying the effect with cross-correlations of the CMB with WISE-PS1.

The ISW effect is widely considered a smoking gun of DE. Thus our measurement is a direct observation of DE, and it is the most statistically significant from a single homogenous data set. In addition, the level of the ISW effect is higher than predicted by the standard concordance model. This rare discordance adds to similar problems with the cosmological expansion rate and cosmic growth of structure. Together, they could signal that we need to refine our cosmological theories.

Our catalogs provide a three-dimensional map of the universe for about half the sky out to over 10 billion light years. The ISW effect is the first low-hanging fruit from this beautiful data set. We expect many interesting scientific analyses, some even beyond our imagination, to follow from our work on this project.
